SEARCH

Class Collation

java.lang.Object
Collation
public class Collation extends Object
The Collation class provides methods for string comparison and transformation based on the collation rules of a specified locale. This class is inspired by collation functions from GNU C and is designed to perform locale-sensitive comparisons and transformations on strings, emulating functionalities similar to strcoll and strxfrm.

  • Method Details

    • compareWithDefaultLocale

      public static int compareWithDefaultLocale(String str1, String str2)
      Compares two strings for collation order using the system's default locale. This function will perform implicit transformation of two strings str1 and str2 to current locale, and conduct comparison. Finally this function will return an integer. Usage Example: 
      
 int result = Collation.compareWithDefaultLocale("foo", "bar");
 if (result < 0) {
      System.out.println("\"foo\" comes before \"bar\"");
 } else if (result > 0) {
     System.out.println("\"foo\" comes after \"bar\"");
 } else {
     System.out.println("\"foo\" is equal to \"bar\"");
 }
      Parameters:
      str1 - This is the first String to be compared.
      str2 - This is the second String to be compared.
      Returns:
      a negative integer if str1 is less than str2. a positive integer if str1 is greater than str2. zero if str1 and str2 are the same.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either str1 or str2 is null

    • compareWithLocale

      public static int compareWithLocale(String str1, String str2, Locale locale)
      Compares two strings for collation order based on specific locale. This function will perform implicit transformation of two strings str1 and str2 to specified locale, and compare under this locale. An integer will be returned after the comparison. Usage Example: 
      
 int result = Collation.compareWithLocale("café", "cafe", Locale.FRENCH);
 if (result < 0) {
     System.out.println("\"café\" comes before \"cafe\" in French collation.");
 } else if (result > 0) {
     System.out.println("\"café\" comes after \"cafe\" in French collation.");
 } else {
     System.out.println("\"café\" is equal to \"cafe\" in French collation.");
 }
      Parameters:
      str1 - This is the first String to be compared.
      str2 - This is the second String to be compared.
      locale - Specific locale where string comparison is performed.
      Returns:
      a negative integer if str1 is less than str2. a positive integer if str1 is greater than str2. zero if str1 and str2 are the same.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either str1 or str2 is null.
      IllegalArgumentException - if locale is null.

    • transformIntoDefaultLocale

      public static String transformIntoDefaultLocale(String source)
      Transforms the source string into a collation key string under the default locale. The transformed string can be used for locale-sensitive comparisons. This function performs explicit transformation of source, with return value representing the transformed String. This method is more simple and intuitive compared with the original one on GNU platform. Usage Example: 
      
 char[] destination = new char[100];
 int transformedLength = Collation.transformWithLocale("example");
      Parameters:
      source - Immutable source string to be transformed.
      Returns:
      The transformed string, using the default locale.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either source or destination is null.

    • transformIntoLocale

      public static String transformIntoLocale(String source, Locale locale)
      Transforms the source string into a collation key string under specified locale. The transformed string can be used for locale-sensitive comparisons. This function performs explicit transformation of source according to specified locale, with return value representing the transformed String. This method is more simple and intuitive compared with the original one on GNU platform. Usage Example: 
      
 char[] destination = new char[100];
 int transformedLength = Collation.transformWithLocale("foo", Locale.US)
      Parameters:
      source - Immutable source string to be transformed.
      locale - Specific locale where string comparison is performed.
      Returns:
      The number of characters needed for full transformation.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either source or destination is null.
      IllegalArgumentException - if locale is null.
